text:
- Islam has a bad
reputation around the world

because it's often linked with
extremists and negativity.
But the reality is that it's a religion
of happiness, kindness, and peace.
In this video, I'm going to share with you

the true beauty of Islam that
you may have never realized.
(exhilarating music)
What's up everyone, Drew Binsky here,

and I've now spent the past
seven days in Mauritania.

It's a country in the
Western part of Africa
in the Sahara Desert.
I'm at the tail end of a seven and a half
month trip all around the world.

And I feel like right now
is was a wonderful time to

share my feelings with you guys
about the religion of Islam.

I've actually spent over
a full year of my life
traveling in Muslim majority countries,

especially as of recently,
having revisited Turkey, Egypt,

Afghanistan, Iraq, Emirates,
Tanzania, and now Mauritania.
In fact, the only Muslim majority country
that I haven't visited is Saudi Arabia,
which I'm hoping to visit soon.
As a Jewish person who grew up
in the United States of America,
I will be the first one to admit
that Islamophobia is a real thing

and I may have suffered
from it at a young age.

But once I started traveling
and opening my eyes up
to other cultures, beliefs, and ideas,

I realized that Islam
is a religion of peace.
You see, there are just about
2 billion Muslims in the world.
- Welcome to Egypt!

- That's about 24% of
the world's population.
So why are they poorly represented
by the actions of only a select few?

Most of my favorite countries
around the world are Muslim.
And I can honestly say that about

half of my 20 current
best friends are Muslim.
So the next time you hear that Jews
and Muslims cannot get along, think again.
In this video I'm going to share with you

a few of the life lessons
I've learned from Islam

and traveling extensively through
Muslim majority countries.
Number one, give respect to everyone.
Respect is the cornerstone of Islam,

and it's seen everywhere, even
among two complete strangers.

People respect the values,
religions, and beliefs of others
even if they aren't the same as theirs.
As an openly Jewish person I've received
nothing but kindness and admiration

when I speak about my
religion and that's something
that I really enjoy about Islam.
I'm Jewish.

- [Drew] I agree.
Another thing I want to mention is

the hand over heart
gesture with a huge smile.

It's commonly used when greeting
someone or saying goodbye

and I've only seen it in
Muslim majority countries.

If that doesn't show
sincerity and respect,
then I don't know what does.
Number two, the home of hospitality.

If there's one thing to take
away from watching this video,

let it be that Muslims take
hospitality to the next level.
They have shown me time and time again
that they are world class at making guests
feel honored, welcome, and comfortable.
He's still giving us food.

Okay, I'll let you explain

I don't think you can get

It's really nice of you.

The same story happened

in Syria and everything would be good.

they would come to Syria,

and we will welcome them and
we welcome them in my house.

And right here in Mauritania, I'm staying

complete strangers who
have never met before,
and they treat me like family.

Every time I try to pay for

I want you to hear me loud and clear.

Muslims are the most
welcoming people in the world.
Number three, incredible family values.

Not only do Muslims treat
strangers with respect,
but they are very polite to one another,
especially the elderly.
In America, we have nursing homes,

but in the world of Islam,
the grandparents are mostly

taken care of by their sons,
daughters, and loved ones.

Inside of a Muslim household
is something very special.
They usually prefer to eat on the floor

and with their hands,
sharing stories, laughter,

and always enjoying a hot
cup of tea at the end.
(Host speaking foreign language)

She's still making more
tea for us, it never ends.
Some people are surprised when they hear
that Muslims don't drink alcohol,

but if you really get down to
it, I don't see a need for it.
Number four, they have immense discipline.

Praying is one of the
five pillars of Islam

and it forms a core of
daily religious observance.

It is obligatory for Muslims
to pray five times a day
at certain times and in a certain way.

Most prayers are happening
inside of mosques,

and I am obsessed with
visiting them around the world.
So we're driving in the middle of Iran
and we pulled over to make a pit stop
at this beautiful shrine.
And I can not tell you guys how incredible
the architecture is here.
We are standing outside of

the Blue Mosque in Mazar-i
Sharif, Afghanistan.
- Yeah.

- There are beautiful places
where time stands still

and you can feel an
overwhelming presence inside.

Right now, I'm inside the
brand new mosque in Dakar

which is the biggest mosque
in Sub Saharan Africa.
And it is just stunning in here.

Muslims are also some
of the cleanest people
you will ever meet.

They wash their hands and feet
every time before praying.
They always take off their shoes indoors.
They clean up after themselves

and always strive to make
the world a better place.

On a final note, it takes
some serious discipline

to fast during the
daylight hours of Ramadan,
the ninth month of the Islamic calendar.
So in conclusion, I urge you not to judge

an entire religion based
off of the headlines

of what you hear on the
news around the world.

I encourage you to travel to
Muslim majority countries,
get inside their homes, speak to them,
eat with your hands on the floor.

That's exactly what I've
been doing here in Mauritania
and it has been absolutely incredible.
- And this is (speaks foreign language).

And after you do all of that,
then you can form your own opinions

and make your own
judgments on the religion.

In fact, I would love to

Please comment below. Let

I really, really appreciate all of you

It doesn't even matter

As I sit here on my very final sunset
in Mauritania on this long trip,
I just want to say thank you guys
for tuning into my stories.

It's been really fun
over the last few months
to document from Venezuela to Iraq,
to Afghanistan and everything in between.
